drunk.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: unable to control your behaviour, speech etc because you have drunk too much alcohol
drunk.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: David would get drunk and I would have to take him home and put him to bed.
All she wants to do is get blind drunk.
He turned up one morning, drunk as a lord.
He was drunk on beer and whisky.
drunk.translation[1].note_box[0].section: having drunk too much alcohol so that your behaviour and mental processes are affected
Gary was too drunk to remember what had happened that night.
I just hope they don’t get drunk and start fighting.
drunk driving
The police are going to crack down on drunk drivers.
tipsy/merry
slightly drunk
After the second glass of wine I was feeling a little tipsy.
pissed
drunk – this word is very common in spoken British English, but it is not polite
Don’t listen to him – he’s pissed.
intoxicated
He was arrested for driving while intoxicated.
paralytic/legless
extremely drunk
Don’t give Dave any more to drink -- he’s already legless.
They became totally paralytic and abusive.
drunken
used to describe someone who is drunk or their behaviour. Drunken is mainly used in written English and is always used before a noun. Don’t say ‘he is drunken’. Say he is drunk
A drunken man was found lying outside a shop door.
We found him lying by the roadside in a drunken stupor (=almost unconscious as a result of being drunk).
drunk.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: someone who is drunk or often gets drunk
